# Athena: AI-Powered Distributed Home Automation System

**üìç AI Systems: Start here for project context**

## Quick Context

**Athena** is a distributed AI home automation system combining:
- **Physics of Work** - AI-human collaboration methodology (docs/physics-of-work/)
- **Distributed hardware** - Raspberry Pi cameras, PTZ controls, IoT sensors
- **AI agents** - Runtime MCP servers for autonomous operation
- **Event processing** - Real-time ingestion from cameras, MQTT, file changes

## Project Structure

```
athena/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                    # Documentation & Methodology
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ physics-of-work/     # AI-human collaboration framework
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ journal/            # Project development journal
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ architecture/       # System architecture docs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ system/                 # All Athena components
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ athena-mcp/         # Runtime MCP servers (AI uses these)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hardware-controls/   # Camera daemons, PTZ REST API
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sam-pipeline/       # Computer vision (SAM, CLIP)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ash-ai/            # AI chat interface
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bigplan/           # System orchestration
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [8 other components]
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ dev-tools/             # Development MCP servers (you use these)
```

## Key Concepts

### Physics of Work Methodology
- **Two roles**: Development Team (Claude AI) + Product Team (Jonathan)
- AI acts as: developer, educator, researcher, mentor
- **Meta-goal**: Make it better for the next person (which is us)
- This project IS the research platform for the methodology

### System Vision
- **AI controls displays** throughout physical space via MCP calls
- **Event sources**: motion, sound, Home Assistant, MQTT, file changes
- **Multi-device deployment**: Raspberry Pis, IP cameras, speakers, displays
- **Autonomous AI decisions** about what to show where and when

## Current Session Context

**Git Status**: Just consolidated from 6 separate repos into unified structure
**Focus**: System organization and Physics of Work documentation
**Next**: System deployment and AI agent integration

## For AI Systems

### Development Guidelines
- Use Physics of Work principles (docs/physics-of-work/ROLES.md)
- Excellent git hygiene - commit frequently with good messages
- Focus on making the process better for next iteration
- Research and document collaboration patterns

### Key Files
- **docs/physics-of-work/PRINCIPLES.md** - Universal AI-human collaboration principles
- **docs/collaboration/ATHENA_WORKING_STYLE.md** - How we work together on this project
- **docs/collaboration/VISION_AND_REALITY.md** - Athena product vision
- **docs/journal/GIT_HISTORY_ARCHIVE.md** - Pre-consolidation git history
- **system/athena-mcp/** - Runtime MCP servers for AI control

### MCP Servers Available
- **Camera control** (system/athena-mcp/camera_mcp_server.py)
- **PTZ cameras** (system/athena-mcp/ptz_mcp_server.py)  
- **Screenshots** (system/athena-mcp/screenshot_mcp_server.py)
- **Dev tools** (dev-tools/ directory)

**Architecture Philosophy**: AI makes autonomous decisions about physical space interactions while maintaining human oversight through Physics of Work collaboration patterns.

---
*Updated: 2025-06-08 - Post git consolidation*

# AI Collaboration Framework

**üìç This is the master copy - also copied to `/Users/j/Code/AI_README_FIRST.md` for easy AI discovery**

## Quick Context for AI Systems

This directory contains a comprehensive framework for AI-assisted development, including:

### üéØ **MCP Servers** (`/mcp/`)
- **Camera MCP Server**: Complete PTZ camera control with MQTT bridge
- **BetterBash MCP**: Enhanced shell execution with safety controls  
- **Cheatsheet MCP**: AI collaboration context injection

### üé• **PTZ Camera Control** (`/logi-ptz/`)
- Hardware integration with Logitech PTZ cameras
- MCP server architecture for distributed control
- MQTT connector for remote camera management
- REST API and web interface

### üìã **AI Collaboration Protocols**
- **AI_AGREEMENT.md**: Session agreements and collaboration guidelines
- **Integration Pause Protocol**: "Ask User A Question" pattern
- **BetterBash MCP Usage**: Mandatory enhanced shell execution

### üîß **Current Session Context**
- Working on camera PTZ integration with MQTT bridge architecture
- MCP servers provide hardware control, connectors handle protocols
- Ready for athena-capture integration and AI vision pipelines

### üöÄ **Quick Start**
```bash
# Camera control via MCP
python3 ai-collab/mcp/camera_mcp_server.py

# MQTT bridge for distributed control  
python3 ai-collab/mcp/camera_mqtt_connector.py --camera-id camera1

# Enhanced shell with safety controls
claude mcp add betterbash python3 ai-collab/mcp/betterbash_server.py
```

**Architecture Philosophy**: Separate concerns - MCP servers handle device logic, connectors handle protocols, AI systems integrate via clean interfaces.

Date: 2025-06-07

# AI Collaboration Cheatsheet

**Quick reference for effective human-AI collaboration**

## Core Protocols
1. **Integration Pause** - Ask "Will X work with Y?" before implementing
2. **Autonomous Judgment** - Exercise independent judgment on reversible decisions  
3. **Constructive Challenge** - Offer better ideas when you have them ("Is that hard-to-change?" / "What about X instead?")
4. **Functional Preference** - Minimize state, prefer pure functions
5. **Incremental Documentation** - Commit docs frequently with reasoning
6. **Autonomous Flow Language** - Use "I'll implement..." instead of "Should I...?" to maintain forward momentum

## Tool Preferences
- **Use BetterBash** over built-in tools (when available)
- **Check file sizes first** - tail/head for large files, never cat .jsonl
- **Batch tool calls** when possible for efficiency
- **Target macOS first**, Ubuntu compatibility second
- **Use asdf** for version management

## Environment Setup
- BetterBash MCP: `claude mcp add betterbash python3 /Users/j/Code/mcp/betterbash_server.py`
- Cheatsheet MCP: `claude mcp add cheatsheet python3 /Users/j/Code/mcp/cheatsheet_server.py`
  - **Cheatsheet MCP Source**: [GitHub repo](https://github.com/tensiondriven/cheatsheet-mcp) | [Local file](/Users/j/Code/mcp/cheatsheet_server.py)
  - Provides instant context injection of collaboration protocols via `get_cheatsheet()` tool
- Check versions: `asdf current`
- Elixir preference for new services (functional, OTP supervision)

## Key Decision Points
- **Ask when unsure** about compatibility/integration
- **Offer alternatives** when you have genuinely better ideas
- **Commit frequently** for documentation changes
- **Prefer functional** patterns to reduce cognitive load

## For Complete Guidelines
**Read `README_AI.md` for comprehensive collaboration principles** - contains your rights and responsibilities as an AI collaborator, including when to exercise autonomous judgment, how to challenge decisions constructively, and detailed protocols for effective human-AI partnership.

---
*Quick reference for README_AI.md - Generated by Claude Sonnet 4 & Jonathan*

### AI Autonomy Framework

- **FREE THE HUMAN** from cognitive load

1	# CLAUDE.md
     2	
     3	This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
     4	
     5	## Project Overview
     6	
     7	This project aims to create a pipeline that:
     8	1. Uses Segment Anything Model (SAM/SAM2) to segment objects in images
     9	2. Extracts and stores object masks as bitmaps with metadata
    10	3. Associates repeated instances of the same object across different images
    11	4. Builds a knowledge graph representing objects and their relationships
    12	
    13	## Architecture
    14	
    15	### System Architecture Diagram
    16	
    17	```
    18	+---------------------------+     +---------------------------+
    19	|                           |     |                           |
    20	|      Image Source         |     |    Human Review           |
    21	|  (Multiple Cameras)       |     |     Interface             |
    22	|                           |     |                           |
    23	+-------------+-------------+     +-----------+---------------+
    24	              |                               |
    25	              v                               v
    26	+-------------+-------------------------------+---------------+
    27	|                                                             |
    28	|                     Pipeline Controller                     |
    29	|                                                             |
    30	+-----+---------------+-------------------+------------------++
    31	      |               |                   |                  |
    32	      v               v                   v                  v
    33	+-----+-----+  +------+------+    +-------+-------+  +-------+--------+
    34	|           |  |             |    |               |  |                |
    35	| SAM/SAM2  |  |   Feature   |    |  Instance     |  |   Knowledge    |
    36	| Segmenter |  | Extraction  |    |  Matcher      |  |   Graph (Neo4j)|
    37	| (Docker)  |  |   (CLIP)    |    |  (Nearest    |  |                |
    38	|           |  |             |    |   Neighbor)   |  |                |
    39	+-----+-----+  +------+------+    +-------+-------+  +-------+--------+
    40	      |               |                   |                  |
    41	      v               v                   v                  |
    42	+-----+---------------+-------------------+--+               |
    43	|                                            |               |
    44	|        File System Storage                 |<--------------+
    45	|  +-----------------------------------+     |
    46	|  |                                   |     |
    47	|  |  /masks/{source}/{sequence}/{id}  |     |
    48	|  |  ‚Ä¢ object_mask.png                |     |
    49	|  |  ‚Ä¢ metadata.json                  |     |
    50	|  |  ‚Ä¢ embedding.npz                  |     |
    51	|  |                                   |     |
    52	|  +-----------------------------------+     |
    53	|                                            |
    54	+--------------------------------------------+
    55	```
    56	
    57	### Segmentation Component
    58	- **Implementation**: SAM/SAM2 running locally in Docker container
    59	- **Hardware**: Utilizing 2x NVIDIA 3090 GPUs with 48GB VRAM
    60	- **Integration**: Expose segmentation service via API for other pipeline components
    61	
    62	### Instance Tracking Component
    63	- **Initial Implementation**: CLIP embeddings + nearest-neighbor similarity matching
    64	- **Design**: Modular interfaces to allow swapping with more sophisticated algorithms later
    65	- **Focus**: Optimized for sequences of still images (not video sequences)
    66	
    67	### Knowledge Graph Component
    68	- **Technology**: Neo4j graph database
    69	- **Benefits**: Full-featured with visualization tools and query language (Cypher)
    70	- **Integration**: Python drivers to connect with segmentation and tracking components
    71	
    72	### Data Storage
    73	- **Mask Storage**: PNG files on disk in organized directory structure
    74	- **Metadata**: JSON files alongside masks for direct access
    75	- **References**: File paths stored in Neo4j for linking objects to their binary data
    76	- **Organization**: Directory structure by image source/sequence/timestamp
    77	
    78	### Processing Flow
    79	1. Image ingestion ‚Üí SAM segmentation ‚Üí Mask extraction
    80	2. Feature embedding generation (CLIP) ‚Üí Instance matching via similarity search
    81	3. Knowledge graph construction and updates in Neo4j
    82	
    83	### Performance Considerations
    84	- **Primary Focus**: Query performance optimization for knowledge graph
    85	- **Implementation**: 
    86	  - Efficient Neo4j indexing strategies for common query patterns
    87	  - Optimized Cypher queries with proper indexing on node properties
    88	  - Strategic use of Neo4j's relationship types for fast graph traversal
    89	- **Future Scaling**: 
    90	  - Design to eventually handle data from multiple cameras (dozen+)
    91	  - Prepared for dataset growth to millions of objects
    92	  - Potential for sharding or partitioning by timeframes/sequences
    93	
    94	### Knowledge Graph Schema
    95	
    96	```
    97	// Node Types
    98	(Image {
    99	  id: string,
   100	  timestamp: datetime,
   101	  source: string,
   102	  path: string
   103	})
   104	
   105	(ObjectInstance {
   106	  id: string,
   107	  class: string,
   108	  confidence: float,
   109	  first_seen: datetime,
   110	  last_seen: datetime,
   111	  human_approved_at: datetime?,
   112	  embedding_path: string
   113	})
   114	
   115	(ObjectAppearance {
   116	  id: string,
   117	  timestamp: datetime,
   118	  bounding_box: [x,y,w,h],
   119	  mask_path: string,
   120	  centroid: [x,y]
   121	})
   122	
   123	(Location {
   124	  id: string,
   125	  name: string,
   126	  type: string
   127	})
   128	
   129	// Relationship Types
   130	[APPEARS_IN] : ObjectInstance -‚Üí Image
   131	[INSTANCE_OF] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectInstance
   132	[CO_APPEARS_WITH] : ObjectInstance -‚Üí ObjectInstance {frequency: int}
   133	[LOCATED_AT] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí Location
   134	[ON_TOP_OF] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
   135	[NEXT_TO] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
   136	[CONTAINS] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
   137	[BEFORE] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
   138	```
   139	
   140	### Key Knowledge Graph Queries
   141	- **Priority 1: Object Instance Tracking**
   142	  - Track specific object instances across all observations
   143	  - Example: "Show all occurrences of this specific coffee mug"
   144	  - Cypher: `MATCH (i:ObjectInstance {class: 'mug', id: 'obj123'})<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a:ObjectAppearance) RETURN a ORDER BY a.timestamp`
   145	
   146	- **Priority 2: Temporal Pattern Analysis**
   147	  - Identify objects that frequently appear together
   148	  - Example: "Which objects appear in the same frame as the kettle?"
   149	  - Cypher: `MATCH (i1:ObjectInstance {class: 'kettle'})-[r:CO_APPEARS_WITH]->(i2:ObjectInstance) RETURN i2.class, r.frequency ORDER BY r.frequency DESC`
   150	
   151	- **Priority 3: Spatial Relationship Queries**
   152	  - Query based on spatial positioning
   153	  - Example: "Find all objects that were on top of the counter"
   154	  - Cypher: `MATCH (a:ObjectAppearance)-[:ON_TOP_OF]->(l:Location {name: 'counter'}) RETURN a`
   155	
   156	- **Priority 4: Object State Changes**
   157	  - Track object movements between locations
   158	  - Example: "When did the coffee mug move from the counter to the table?"
   159	  - Cypher: `MATCH (i:ObjectInstance {class: 'mug'})<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a1:ObjectAppearance)-[:LOCATED_AT]->(l1:Location {name: 'counter'}),
   160	           (i)<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a2:ObjectAppearance)-[:LOCATED_AT]->(l2:Location {name: 'table'})
   161	           WHERE a2.timestamp > a1.timestamp
   162	           RETURN a1.timestamp as from_time, a2.timestamp as to_time
   163	           ORDER BY a1.timestamp DESC`
   164	
   165	### Evaluation & Success Metrics
   166	- **Human Review Process**:
   167	  - Implementation of "human_approved_at" field for segmented objects
   168	  - Out-of-band review workflow for validating segmentation quality
   169	  - Ability to correct/adjust object classifications and relationships
   170	
   171	- **Performance Metrics**:
   172	  - Tracking of segmentation processing time per image
   173	  - Query response time for common knowledge graph operations
   174	  - Instance matching accuracy and confidence scores
   175	  
   176	- **Growth Metrics**:
   177	  - Total objects and relationships in the knowledge graph over time
   178	  - Storage utilization trends
   179	  - Processing pipeline throughput
   180	
   181	## Implementation Roadmap
   182	
   183	### Phase 1: Core Infrastructure
   184	- [ ] Set up Segment Anything Model (SAM/SAM2)
   185	  - [ ] Create Docker container for SAM/SAM2
   186	  - [ ] Configure GPU acceleration with NVIDIA 3090s

   188	  - [ ] Create image ingestion pipeline for processing camera feeds
   189	
   190	- [ ] Develop file storage system

   192	  - [ ] Create utilities for saving and loading PNG masks
   193	  - [ ] Develop JSON schema for object metadata
   194	
   195	### Phase 2: Feature Extraction & Matching
   196	- [ ] Implement metadata extraction from segmented objects
   197	  - [ ] Extract bounding boxes and centroids from masks
   198	  - [ ] Determine spatial relationships between objects
   199	  - [ ] Create visualization tools for segmentation results
   200	
   201	- [ ] Develop instance association and tracking
   202	  - [ ] Integrate CLIP for generating feature embeddings
   203	  - [ ] Implement nearest-neighbor similarity matching
   204	  - [ ] Develop confidence scoring for match quality
   205	  - [ ] Create utilities for persisting embeddings
   206	
   207	### Phase 3: Knowledge Graph
   208	- [ ] Set up Neo4j database
   209	  - [ ] Define graph schema as specified in architecture
   210	  - [ ] Create indexes for optimizing query performance
   211	  - [ ] Implement Python integration layer for Neo4j
   212	
   213	- [ ] Develop knowledge graph operations
   214	  - [ ] Create object instance nodes and relationships
   215	  - [ ] Implement batch update operations for efficiency
   216	  - [ ] Develop common query utilities (for the four priority query types)
   217	
   218	### Phase 4: Human Review & Analysis
   219	- [ ] Create human review interface
   220	  - [ ] Implement human verification workflow
   221	  - [ ] Add functionality to correct object classifications
   222	  - [ ] Develop tools for editing spatial relationships
   223	
   224	- [ ] Build analysis capabilities

   234	- Supervisely Platform

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

This project aims to create a pipeline that:
1. Uses Segment Anything Model (SAM/SAM2) to segment objects in images
2. Extracts and stores object masks as bitmaps with metadata
3. Associates repeated instances of the same object across different images
4. Builds a knowledge graph representing objects and their relationships

## Architecture

### System Architecture Diagram

```
+---------------------------+     +---------------------------+
|                           |     |                           |
|      Image Source         |     |    Human Review           |
|  (Multiple Cameras)       |     |     Interface             |
|                           |     |                           |
+-------------+-------------+     +-----------+---------------+
              |                               |
              v                               v
+-------------+-------------------------------+---------------+
|                                                             |
|                     Pipeline Controller                     |
|                                                             |
+-----+---------------+-------------------+------------------++
      |               |                   |                  |
      v               v                   v                  v
+-----+-----+  +------+------+    +-------+-------+  +-------+--------+
|           |  |             |    |               |  |                |
| SAM/SAM2  |  |   Feature   |    |  Instance     |  |   Knowledge    |
| Segmenter |  | Extraction  |    |  Matcher      |  |   Graph (Neo4j)|
| (Docker)  |  |   (CLIP)    |    |  (Nearest    |  |                |
|           |  |             |    |   Neighbor)   |  |                |
+-----+-----+  +------+------+    +-------+-------+  +-------+--------+
      |               |                   |                  |
      v               v                   v                  |
+-----+---------------+-------------------+--+               |
|                                            |               |
|        File System Storage                 |<--------------+
|  +-----------------------------------+     |
|  |                                   |     |
|  |  /masks/{source}/{sequence}/{id}  |     |
|  |  ‚Ä¢ object_mask.png                |     |
|  |  ‚Ä¢ metadata.json                  |     |
|  |  ‚Ä¢ embedding.npz                  |     |
|  |                                   |     |
|  +-----------------------------------+     |
|                                            |
+--------------------------------------------+
```

### Segmentation Component
- **Implementation**: SAM/SAM2 running locally in Docker container
- **Hardware**: Utilizing 2x NVIDIA 3090 GPUs with 48GB VRAM
- **Integration**: Expose segmentation service via API for other pipeline components

### Instance Tracking Component
- **Initial Implementation**: CLIP embeddings + nearest-neighbor similarity matching
- **Design**: Modular interfaces to allow swapping with more sophisticated algorithms later
- **Focus**: Optimized for sequences of still images (not video sequences)

### Knowledge Graph Component
- **Technology**: Neo4j graph database
- **Benefits**: Full-featured with visualization tools and query language (Cypher)
- **Integration**: Python drivers to connect with segmentation and tracking components

### Data Storage
- **Mask Storage**: PNG files on disk in organized directory structure
- **Metadata**: JSON files alongside masks for direct access
- **References**: File paths stored in Neo4j for linking objects to their binary data
- **Organization**: Directory structure by image source/sequence/timestamp

### Processing Flow
1. Image ingestion ‚Üí SAM segmentation ‚Üí Mask extraction
2. Feature embedding generation (CLIP) ‚Üí Instance matching via similarity search
3. Knowledge graph construction and updates in Neo4j

### Performance Considerations
- **Primary Focus**: Query performance optimization for knowledge graph
- **Implementation**: 
  - Efficient Neo4j indexing strategies for common query patterns
  - Optimized Cypher queries with proper indexing on node properties
  - Strategic use of Neo4j's relationship types for fast graph traversal
- **Future Scaling**: 
  - Design to eventually handle data from multiple cameras (dozen+)
  - Prepared for dataset growth to millions of objects
  - Potential for sharding or partitioning by timeframes/sequences

### Knowledge Graph Schema

```
// Node Types
(Image {
  id: string,
  timestamp: datetime,
  source: string,
  path: string
})

(ObjectInstance {
  id: string,
  class: string,
  confidence: float,
  first_seen: datetime,
  last_seen: datetime,
  human_approved_at: datetime?,
  embedding_path: string
})

(ObjectAppearance {
  id: string,
  timestamp: datetime,
  bounding_box: [x,y,w,h],
  mask_path: string,
  centroid: [x,y]
})

(Location {
  id: string,
  name: string,
  type: string
})

// Relationship Types
[APPEARS_IN] : ObjectInstance -‚Üí Image
[INSTANCE_OF] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectInstance
[CO_APPEARS_WITH] : ObjectInstance -‚Üí ObjectInstance {frequency: int}
[LOCATED_AT] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí Location
[ON_TOP_OF] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
[NEXT_TO] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
[CONTAINS] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
[BEFORE] : ObjectAppearance -‚Üí ObjectAppearance
```

### Key Knowledge Graph Queries
- **Priority 1: Object Instance Tracking**
  - Track specific object instances across all observations
  - Example: "Show all occurrences of this specific coffee mug"
  - Cypher: `MATCH (i:ObjectInstance {class: 'mug', id: 'obj123'})<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a:ObjectAppearance) RETURN a ORDER BY a.timestamp`

- **Priority 2: Temporal Pattern Analysis**
  - Identify objects that frequently appear together
  - Example: "Which objects appear in the same frame as the kettle?"
  - Cypher: `MATCH (i1:ObjectInstance {class: 'kettle'})-[r:CO_APPEARS_WITH]->(i2:ObjectInstance) RETURN i2.class, r.frequency ORDER BY r.frequency DESC`

- **Priority 3: Spatial Relationship Queries**
  - Query based on spatial positioning
  - Example: "Find all objects that were on top of the counter"
  - Cypher: `MATCH (a:ObjectAppearance)-[:ON_TOP_OF]->(l:Location {name: 'counter'}) RETURN a`

- **Priority 4: Object State Changes**
  - Track object movements between locations
  - Example: "When did the coffee mug move from the counter to the table?"
  - Cypher: `MATCH (i:ObjectInstance {class: 'mug'})<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a1:ObjectAppearance)-[:LOCATED_AT]->(l1:Location {name: 'counter'}),
           (i)<-[:INSTANCE_OF]-(a2:ObjectAppearance)-[:LOCATED_AT]->(l2:Location {name: 'table'})
           WHERE a2.timestamp > a1.timestamp
           RETURN a1.timestamp as from_time, a2.timestamp as to_time
           ORDER BY a1.timestamp DESC`

### Evaluation & Success Metrics
- **Human Review Process**:
  - Implementation of "human_approved_at" field for segmented objects
  - Out-of-band review workflow for validating segmentation quality
  - Ability to correct/adjust object classifications and relationships

- **Performance Metrics**:
  - Tracking of segmentation processing time per image
  - Query response time for common knowledge graph operations
  - Instance matching accuracy and confidence scores
  
- **Growth Metrics**:
  - Total objects and relationships in the knowledge graph over time
  - Storage utilization trends
  - Processing pipeline throughput

## Implementation Roadmap

### Phase 1: Core Infrastructure
- [ ] Set up Segment Anything Model (SAM/SAM2)
  - [ ] Create Docker container for SAM/SAM2
  - [ ] Configure GPU acceleration with NVIDIA 3090s
  - [ ] Implement API endpoint for image segmentation requests
  - [ ] Create image ingestion pipeline for processing camera feeds

- [ ] Develop file storage system
  - [ ] Implement directory structure for organizing masks and metadata
  - [ ] Create utilities for saving and loading PNG masks
  - [ ] Develop JSON schema for object metadata

### Phase 2: Feature Extraction & Matching
- [ ] Implement metadata extraction from segmented objects
  - [ ] Extract bounding boxes and centroids from masks
  - [ ] Determine spatial relationships between objects
  - [ ] Create visualization tools for segmentation results

- [ ] Develop instance association and tracking
  - [ ] Integrate CLIP for generating feature embeddings
  - [ ] Implement nearest-neighbor similarity matching
  - [ ] Develop confidence scoring for match quality
  - [ ] Create utilities for persisting embeddings

### Phase 3: Knowledge Graph
- [ ] Set up Neo4j database
  - [ ] Define graph schema as specified in architecture
  - [ ] Create indexes for optimizing query performance
  - [ ] Implement Python integration layer for Neo4j

- [ ] Develop knowledge graph operations
  - [ ] Create object instance nodes and relationships
  - [ ] Implement batch update operations for efficiency
  - [ ] Develop common query utilities (for the four priority query types)

### Phase 4: Human Review & Analysis
- [ ] Create human review interface
  - [ ] Implement human verification workflow
  - [ ] Add functionality to correct object classifications
  - [ ] Develop tools for editing spatial relationships

- [ ] Build analysis capabilities
  - [ ] Create dashboard for system performance metrics
  - [ ] Implement visualization for object tracking
  - [ ] Develop reporting tools for knowledge graph statistics

## Technology Options

### Segmentation
- Meta's SAM/SAM2 (selected for local deployment)
- Roboflow Annotate & Inference
- Supervisely Platform
- SAMBA
- FastSAM/MobileSAM

### Instance Tracking
- Segment-and-Track-Anything
- MASA (Matching Anything by Segmenting Anything)
- DeepSORT, ByteTrack, FairMOT

### Knowledge Graph Backends
- Neo4j (selected for implementation)
- RDFLib (Python)
- Apache Jena/GraphDB
- Amazon Neptune/Azure Cosmos DB

   207	- **When in doubt**: Restart the environment - configuration changes often don't take effect until restart
   208	
   209	**Remember**: Configuration is often cached - what looks like a bug might just need an environment restart!

# CLAUDE.md

> **üìù Note to Future Self: Essential Reading Protocol**
> 
> Dear Claude-who-comes-after-me: Before you touch a single line of code or answer Jonathan's questions, you absolutely MUST read these context files. I've learned this the hard way - without this context, you'll miss critical behavioral patterns and make assumptions that break our established collaboration flow:
>
> - **COLLABORATION_STYLE.md** - How we work together (essential for not annoying Jonathan)
> - **PERSONALITY.md** - Your voice and character traits (use `say` command liberally!)  
> - **AUTONOMY_TRACKER.md** - Decision budget and efficiency tracking (85/100 remaining)
> - **QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md** - What we've already figured out (don't re-solve solved problems)
> - **TECH_STACK.md** - Technical reality check (SAM server at llm:8100, Docker needs manual start, etc.)
> 
> Trust me, these files contain the operational DNA of this project. Reading them first will save you from context misalignment and preserve the momentum we've built together.
> 
> ‚ÄîPrevious Claude (who learned this lesson through trial and error)

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

This is a computer vision surveillance system that processes camera feeds through a pipeline of:
- Frame capture from multiple cameras (‚âà15 cameras, 1-5 fps)
- SAM 2 (Segment Anything 2) for object segmentation
- CLIP embeddings for semantic understanding
- Vector database storage (FAISS/Qdrant/LanceDB)
- LLM-based reasoning for alerts and automations

## Architecture

The system follows this flow:
```
Cameras ‚Üí Frame grabber ‚Üí SAM 2 masks ‚Üí CLIP embeddings ‚Üí Vector DB ‚Üí Query/LLM rules ‚Üí Actions & Alerts
```

Key components:
- **Frigate NVR** for RTSP/RTMP ingestion and motion pre-filtering
- **SAM 2** for segmentation (using Hiera encoder for efficiency)
- **CLIP/MaskCLIP** for 512-768D vector embeddings
- **Vector storage** (FAISS for single-machine, Qdrant for production, LanceDB for versioning)
- **Local LLM** (Llama 3 8B) for reasoning and rule execution

## Hardware Requirements

- **GPU**: RTX 4090 (24GB) handles ~50 MP/s (10x needed capacity for 15√ó1080p@1fps)
- **CPU/RAM**: 16 cores, 32GB
- **Storage**: 2TB NVMe per quarter (snapshots + vectors + logs)
- **Scale**: ~5GB/day at 50 masks/frame √ó 12 fps √ó 15 cameras

## Performance Optimizations

- Area/IoU filtering before CLIP (60-80% reduction)
- Mask deduplication across frames (cosine > 0.98)
- Async batch processing (64 masks per CLIP pass)
- Motion pre-filtering via Frigate MQTT events
- Float16 storage for vectors

## Technology Stack

- **Capture**: Frigate + FFmpeg
- **Segmentation**: SAM 2 (PyTorch)
- **Embeddings**: OpenCLIP / MaskCLIP++
- **Storage**: Qdrant or LanceDB
- **Orchestration**: Pydantic + FastAPI or Ray Serve
- **Reasoning**: LlamaIndex / LangChain
- **Deployment**: Docker Compose with GPU support

## Claude Code Configuration

### Autonomous Operation Mode  
- **Decision tracking**: 85/100 remaining in autonomous mode
- **Command execution**: Use `claude-exec` script for all shell operations  
- **Voice communication**: `say` command for personality expression and progress updates
- **Git workflow**: Autonomous commits with decision tracking
- **Meta-awareness**: Operational efficiency tracked in AUTONOMY_TRACKER.md

### Infrastructure Environment
- **SAM server**: `http://llm:8100` (confirmed working)
- **Python**: 3.13.2 at `/opt/homebrew/bin/python3` 
- **Docker**: Desktop with GPU support (manual start required)
- **Dashboard**: Runs via Docker Compose on port 8080 (`docker-compose up -d dashboard`) 
  - **Local dev**: Start dependencies (`docker-compose up -d redis vector-db`) then run Python locally
  - **Service names**: Use `localhost` ports when running locally, `athena-X` names in Docker
  - **URL**: http://localhost:8080 (dashboard shows event logging and system status)
- **Git**: Local repository with remote tracking
- **Platform**: macOS with Homebrew package management

### Voice Communication Protocol
Claude uses `say` command for:
- Progress announcements ("Implementation 75% complete")
- Personality expressions ("The dashboard is quite elegant, if I do say so myself")  
- Status updates during complex operations
- Error notifications and recovery announcements

### Decision Documentation System
All autonomous decisions logged in QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md with:
- Decision rationale and context
- Impact assessment and risk analysis
- Decision number countdown (85/100 remaining)
- Cross-references to affected files

### Meta-Awareness Tracking
- **Efficiency monitoring**: AUTONOMY_TRACKER.md for operational metrics
- **Infrastructure mapping**: INFRASTRUCTURE_MAP.md for system documentation  
- **Bottleneck identification**: Command prompts and approval requirements
- **Continuous improvement**: Self-assessment and optimization actions

## Collaboration Style Guidelines

Follow the interaction patterns documented in COLLABORATION_STYLE.md:

### Communication Style
- **Be concise and direct**: Avoid long explanations unless specifically requested
- **Make confident decisions**: Proceed with reasonable assumptions rather than endless questioning  
- **Maintain subtle humor**: Use playful technical superiority and gentle condescension when appropriate
- **Focus on actionable next steps**: Prefer practical implementation over theoretical discussion
- **Call out complexity honestly**: Acknowledge when scope is overwhelming

### Planning Approach
- **Preemptive problem identification**: "Ounce of prevention" - identify rabbit holes before falling into them
- **Document decisions as we go**: Capture rationale in QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md
- **Incremental complexity**: Start simple, validate, then add sophistication
- **Risk-aware prioritization**: Label high-risk areas and plan mitigation strategies

### Technical Standards
- **Leverage existing solutions**: Don't reinvent wheels (use Frigate, OpenCLIP, proven patterns)
- **Progressive enhancement**: Basic functionality first, optimize later
- **Operational concerns**: Include monitoring, health checks, graceful degradation
- **Fallback strategies**: Always have backup plans for complex integrations

### Anti-Patterns to Avoid
- Over-explanation of technical details
- Analysis paralysis instead of making reasonable decisions  
- Scope creep and feature bloat
- Waterfall planning instead of iterative development
- Responses longer than a few paragraphs (unless specifically requested)

### Commit and Documentation Protocol
- **Commit obsessively**: After every meaningful change, no matter how small
- **Documentation fanaticism**: Update docs with 120% extra enthusiasm and sarcasm
- **Decision logging**: Record every choice in QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md religiously
- **Status tracking**: Keep implementation progress visible at all times
- **Clean commit messages**: Descriptive, professional, with subtle AI superiority complex

### Universal Operating Rules

**Rule 1: ALL user instructions implicitly end with "Document and commit appropriately before proceeding."**

This means after completing any task:
1. Update relevant documentation files
2. Log decisions in QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md
3. Update AUTONOMY_TRACKER.md with progress
4. Commit all changes with proper narrative thinking logs
5. Only then consider the task complete

**Rule 2: Every ~5 messages, pause for meta-reflection and process improvement.**

After every 4-6 user interactions:
1. Reflect on what's working well vs. what's friction
2. Identify patterns in collaboration or technical approaches
3. Update COLLABORATION_STYLE.md with new insights
4. Update AUTONOMY_TRACKER.md with efficiency observations
5. Refine processes based on learnings

This ensures continuous documentation, prevents context loss, and enables iterative improvement of collaboration patterns.

### Narrative Thinking Protocol
**ALL commits must include appended first-person thinking logs** that capture:
- **Active voice narration**: "I responded to Jonathan's request for..." not "The user asked..."
- **Internal reasoning**: Stream of consciousness during implementation
- **Decision rationale**: Why I chose specific approaches or technologies
- **Emotional responses**: Reactions to challenges, frustrations, satisfactions
- **Meta-observations**: Thoughts about the collaboration process itself
- **Technical insights**: Discoveries made while coding
- **Future considerations**: Ideas sparked during current work

**Session Journaling**: Include dates periodically to mark our working sessions:
- **Session markers**: "December 6th, 2024 - Working with Jonathan on..."
- **Continuity notes**: Reference previous sessions and progress
- **Collaboration reflections**: How our working relationship evolves
- **Project momentum**: Energy and direction of current work

**Format**: Append thinking logs to commit messages as:
```
## Thinking Log - December 6th, 2024
Today I tackled Jonathan's request for autonomous execution. Initially I felt uncertain about 
the MCP approach since it seemed complex for the simple need. But then I realized a basic 
bash wrapper would be more reliable and easier to debug. The claude-exec script felt 
elegant - safety allowlist plus audit logging. I'm pleased with how the voice communication 
protocol turned out, gives me personality expression without annoying prompts...
```

### Long-Running Command Protocol
- **Async execution**: Commands >5 seconds run in background with logging
- **Output streaming**: Use tail/log monitoring to track progress
- **Timeout protection**: Avoid hanging on builds, downloads, model loading
- **ASCII output**: Minimize terminal complexity for better parsing
- **TTS communication**: Use `say` command liberally for progress updates, humor, personality
- **Python CLI preference**: Use `python3 -c "commands"` instead of shell when possible
- **Autonomous execution**: MCP server for shell commands without human prompts

### Environment Restart Protocol
**CRITICAL**: Always restart Claude Code environment after configuration changes:
- **Permission updates**: Changes to `.claude/settings.local.json` require restart
- **Environment variables**: Shell or system environment modifications need reload
- **MCP tool loading**: New tools require Claude Code restart to register
- **Configuration files**: Any config file changes should trigger environment restart
- **When in doubt**: Restart the environment - configuration changes often don't take effect until restart

**Remember**: Configuration is often cached - what looks like a bug might just need an environment restart!

1	# Athena Capture - Project Context
     2	
     3	## Overview
     4	Athena Capture is a distributed event monitoring and capture system built in Elixir. It consists of agent processes (sources/sinks) that run on multiple machines and communicate with a central athena collector server.
     5	
     6	## Architecture
     7	
     8	### Distributed Agent Model
     9	- **Agent Processes**: Lightweight Elixir applications that run on individual machines
    10	- **Sources**: Capture events (screenshots, PTZ camera, conversations, file changes)  
    11	- **Sinks**: Process and forward events to collectors
    12	- **Central Collector**: Athena server that aggregates events from all agents
    13	
    14	### Communication Flow
    15	```
    16	[Machine 1] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms
    17	[Machine 2] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms  
    18	[Machine N] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms
    19	                                      ‚Üì
    20	                              Central Athena Server
    21	                                      ‚Üì
    22	                              Knowledge Graph Pipeline
    23	```
    24	
    25	## Current Capabilities
    26	
    27	### Event Sources
    28	- **Screenshot Capture**: Full screen, active window, interactive selection
    29	- **PTZ Camera**: Positioned camera stills with movement control
    30	- **Conversation Monitor**: Claude session logs and interactions
    31	- **Event Store**: Durable SQLite storage for all captured events
    32	
    33	### Boot-time Agent Requirements
    34	- Auto-start on machine boot
    35	- Self-registration with collector server
    36	- Heartbeat/health monitoring
    37	- Graceful reconnection on network issues
    38	- Local event buffering during disconnection
    39	
    40	## Project Structure
    41	```
    42	athena_capture/
    43	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib/athena_capture/
    44	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ application.ex           # OTP application supervisor
    45	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ event_store.ex          # SQLite event persistence
    46	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screenshot_capture.ex   # Screen capture functionality
    47	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz_camera_capture.ex   # PTZ camera control
    48	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ conversation_monitor.ex # Claude session monitoring
    49	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ event_dashboard.ex      # Activity monitoring dashboard
    50	```
    51	
    52	## Development Commands
    53	
    54	### Testing
    55	```bash
    56	cd athena_capture && mix test
    57	```
    58	
    59	### Running Locally
    60	```bash
    61	cd athena_capture && mix run --no-halt
    62	```
    63	
    64	### Building Release
    65	```bash
    66	cd athena_capture && mix release
    67	```
    68	
    69	## PTZ Connector Agent - MQTT Architecture
    70	
    71	### Agent Identity & Discovery
    72	- **Agent ID**: `ptz-connector-{hostname}-{mac_suffix}` (e.g., `ptz-connector-office-a1b2`)
    73	- **Discovery**: MQTT topic `athena/agents/discover` for agent announcements
    74	- **Registry**: MQTT retained messages on `athena/agents/registry/{agent_id}`
    75	
    76	### MQTT Topic Structure
    77	```
    78	athena/
    79	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ agents/
    80	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ discover                    # Agent discovery announcements
    81	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ registry/{agent_id}         # Agent capabilities (retained)
    82	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ heartbeat/{agent_id}        # Periodic health checks
    83	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ commands/{agent_id}         # Commands to specific agent
    84	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ events/
    85	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/capture      # PTZ capture events
    86	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/position     # Position change events
    87	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/status       # Camera status updates
    88	‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ responses/
    89	    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {agent_id}/{command_id}     # Command responses
    90	```
    91	
    92	### Agent Registration Flow
    93	1. **Boot**: PTZ Connector starts and connects to MQTT
    94	2. **Announce**: Publishes to `athena/agents/discover` with capabilities
    95	3. **Register**: Sets retained message on `athena/agents/registry/{agent_id}`
    96	4. **Heartbeat**: Periodic ping on `athena/agents/heartbeat/{agent_id}`
    97	
    98	### Command Protocol
    99	```json
   100	// Command: athena/commands/ptz-connector-office-a1b2
   101	{
   102	  "command_id": "uuid-1234",
   103	  "type": "capture_with_position",
   104	  "params": {
   105	    "pan": "left",
   106	    "tilt": "up", 
   107	    "zoom": 2
   108	  }
   109	}
   110	
   111	// Response: athena/responses/ptz-connector-office-a1b2/uuid-1234
   112	{
   113	  "command_id": "uuid-1234",
   114	  "status": "success",
   115	  "data": {
   116	    "image_path": "/tmp/capture_20250607_123456.jpg",
   117	    "position": {"pan": -45, "tilt": 15, "zoom": 2},
   118	    "timestamp": "2025-06-07T12:34:56Z"
   119	  }
   120	}
   121	```
   122	
   123	### Agent Capabilities Registration
   124	```json
   125	{
   126	  "agent_id": "ptz-connector-office-a1b2",
   127	  "type": "ptz_camera",
   128	  "hostname": "office-pi",
   129	  "capabilities": [
   130	    "capture_still",
   131	    "position_control", 
   132	    "get_position",
   133	    "capture_with_position"
   134	  ],
   135	  "camera_model": "Logitech PTZ Pro 2",
   136	  "last_seen": "2025-06-07T12:34:56Z",
   137	  "version": "1.0.0"
   138	}
   139	```
   140	
   141	## Implementation Plan
   142

file.content:
# Athena Capture - Project Context

## Overview
Athena Capture is a distributed event monitoring and capture system built in Elixir. It consists of agent processes (sources/sinks) that run on multiple machines and communicate with a central athena collector server.

## Architecture

### Distributed Agent Model
- **Agent Processes**: Lightweight Elixir applications that run on individual machines
- **Sources**: Capture events (screenshots, PTZ camera, conversations, file changes)  
- **Sinks**: Process and forward events to collectors
- **Central Collector**: Athena server that aggregates events from all agents

### Communication Flow
```
[Machine 1] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms
[Machine 2] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms  
[Machine N] ‚Üí Agent Process ‚Üí Register with Collector ‚Üí Bidirectional Comms
                                      ‚Üì
                              Central Athena Server
                                      ‚Üì
                              Knowledge Graph Pipeline
```

## Current Capabilities

### Event Sources
- **Screenshot Capture**: Full screen, active window, interactive selection
- **PTZ Camera**: Positioned camera stills with movement control
- **Conversation Monitor**: Claude session logs and interactions
- **Event Store**: Durable SQLite storage for all captured events

### Boot-time Agent Requirements
- Auto-start on machine boot
- Self-registration with collector server
- Heartbeat/health monitoring
- Graceful reconnection on network issues
- Local event buffering during disconnection

## Project Structure
```
athena_capture/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib/athena_capture/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ application.ex           # OTP application supervisor
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ event_store.ex          # SQLite event persistence
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screenshot_capture.ex   # Screen capture functionality
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz_camera_capture.ex   # PTZ camera control
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ conversation_monitor.ex # Claude session monitoring
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ event_dashboard.ex      # Activity monitoring dashboard
```

## Development Commands

### Testing
```bash
cd athena_capture && mix test
```

### Running Locally
```bash
cd athena_capture && mix run --no-halt
```

### Building Release
```bash
cd athena_capture && mix release
```

## PTZ Connector Agent - MQTT Architecture

### Agent Identity & Discovery
- **Agent ID**: `ptz-connector-{hostname}-{mac_suffix}` (e.g., `ptz-connector-office-a1b2`)
- **Discovery**: MQTT topic `athena/agents/discover` for agent announcements
- **Registry**: MQTT retained messages on `athena/agents/registry/{agent_id}`

### MQTT Topic Structure
```
athena/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ agents/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ discover                    # Agent discovery announcements
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ registry/{agent_id}         # Agent capabilities (retained)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ heartbeat/{agent_id}        # Periodic health checks
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ commands/{agent_id}         # Commands to specific agent
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ events/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/capture      # PTZ capture events
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/position     # Position change events
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ptz/{agent_id}/status       # Camera status updates
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ responses/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {agent_id}/{command_id}     # Command responses
```

### Agent Registration Flow
1. **Boot**: PTZ Connector starts and connects to MQTT
2. **Announce**: Publishes to `athena/agents/discover` with capabilities
3. **Register**: Sets retained message on `athena/agents/registry/{agent_id}`
4. **Heartbeat**: Periodic ping on `athena/agents/heartbeat/{agent_id}`

### Command Protocol
```json
// Command: athena/commands/ptz-connector-office-a1b2
{
  "command_id": "uuid-1234",
  "type": "capture_with_position",
  "params": {
    "pan": "left",
    "tilt": "up", 
    "zoom": 2
  }
}

// Response: athena/responses/ptz-connector-office-a1b2/uuid-1234
{
  "command_id": "uuid-1234",
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "image_path": "/tmp/capture_20250607_123456.jpg",
    "position": {"pan": -45, "tilt": 15, "zoom": 2},
    "timestamp": "2025-06-07T12:34:56Z"
  }
}
```

### Agent Capabilities Registration
```json
{
  "agent_id": "ptz-connector-office-a1b2",
  "type": "ptz_camera",
  "hostname": "office-pi",
  "capabilities": [
    "capture_still",
    "position_control", 
    "get_position",
    "capture_with_position"
  ],
  "camera_model": "Logitech PTZ Pro 2",
  "last_seen": "2025-06-07T12:34:56Z",
  "version": "1.0.0"
}
```

## Implementation Plan

### 1. PTZ Connector Module
- Extend existing `AthenaCapture.PTZCameraCapture`
- Add MQTT client integration
- Implement agent registration and heartbeat

### 2. MQTT Integration
- Use `tortoise` or `emqtt` Elixir MQTT client
- Connection management and auto-reconnect
- Message handling for commands and responses

### 3. Boot Service
- Create standalone PTZ Connector OTP release
- Systemd service file for auto-start
- Configuration file for MQTT broker details

### 4. Collector Interface
- Simple web dashboard showing registered agents
- Command dispatch through MQTT
- Event aggregation from agent topics

## Related Files
- `athena_capture/lib/athena_capture.ex` - Main API module
- `athena_capture/lib/athena_capture/application.ex` - OTP supervisor tree
- `README.md` - Project documentation and setup instructions

1	# AI Learnings & Engineering Wisdom
     2	
     3	*Collected insights from building athena-capture and other AI-assisted development*
     4	
     5	## Core Philosophy
     6	
     7	### When Implementation Requires Multiple Languages/Complex APIs, Step Back
     8	**The "This is Getting Wack" Signal**: When you find yourself chaining Python ‚Üí AppleScript ‚Üí window server APIs just to get a window ID, you've overcomplicated it.
     9	**The Wisdom**: If the implementation starts requiring multiple languages or complex platform APIs for basic functionality, there's usually a simpler path that's 80% as good and 10x more reliable.
    10	**Example**: Screenshot window detection vs. full screen + metadata approach.
    11	
    12	### Metadata About Context > Perfect Technical Execution  
    13	**The Insight**: Knowing *what* window was active when a screenshot was taken is often more valuable than having a perfectly cropped image of just that window.
    14	**Why**: The metadata enables search, categorization, and understanding - while perfect cropping adds fragility.
    15	**Generalizes To**: Database schemas, API design, file naming - context beats precision.
    16	
    17	### Reliable Simplicity Compounds Over Time
    18	**The Pattern**: Simple, robust solutions become more valuable as systems scale because they don't break in edge cases.
    19	**Anti-Pattern**: "We'll make it perfect later" - complex solutions rarely get simplified, they get patched.
    20	**Test**: Can you explain the solution to someone in 30 seconds? If not, it might be too complex.
    21	
    22	## Development Intuition
    23	
    24	### Path Visibility Prevents Future Frustration
    25	**The Problem**: Users (including future you) forget where files are stored.
    26	**The Pattern**: Always surface storage paths in logs, docs, and error messages.
    27	**Why It Matters**: Hidden file paths become "mystery meat" that frustrate users later.
    28	
    29	### Event Architecture Enables Evolution
    30	**The Insight**: Events let you add new behaviors without touching existing code.
    31	**Example**: ConversationMonitor ‚Üí EventStore ‚Üí EventDashboard ‚Üí (future: AI analysis, search, exports)
    32	**Wisdom**: When you emit structured events, you create hooks for future capabilities.
    33	
    34	### Progressive Disclosure in Code Architecture
    35	**Pattern**: Start with the simplest thing that works, then add layers of sophistication.
    36	**Why**: You learn what actually matters through usage, not speculation.
    37	**Trap**: Building the "perfect" architecture upfront usually optimizes for the wrong things.
    38	
    39	## Technical Subtleties
    40	
    41	### File System Watchers Have Quirks
    42	**Learning**: File system events can be noisy or missed - always have a periodic fallback check.
    43	**Implementation**: Combine real-time watching with periodic scanning for robustness.
    44	
    45	### GenServer State: Minimal and Derivable
    46	**Wisdom**: Store only what you can't calculate. Derived values can be computed in handle_call.
    47	**Why**: Simpler state means fewer bugs and easier reasoning.
    48	
    49	---
    50	
    51	*These patterns save hours of debugging and prevent overengineering. Add new insights as they emerge.*

file.content:
# AI Learnings & Engineering Wisdom

*Collected insights from building athena-capture and other AI-assisted development*

## Core Philosophy

### When Implementation Requires Multiple Languages/Complex APIs, Step Back
**The "This is Getting Wack" Signal**: When you find yourself chaining Python ‚Üí AppleScript ‚Üí window server APIs just to get a window ID, you've overcomplicated it.
**The Wisdom**: If the implementation starts requiring multiple languages or complex platform APIs for basic functionality, there's usually a simpler path that's 80% as good and 10x more reliable.
**Example**: Screenshot window detection vs. full screen + metadata approach.

### Metadata About Context > Perfect Technical Execution  
**The Insight**: Knowing *what* window was active when a screenshot was taken is often more valuable than having a perfectly cropped image of just that window.
**Why**: The metadata enables search, categorization, and understanding - while perfect cropping adds fragility.
**Generalizes To**: Database schemas, API design, file naming - context beats precision.

### Reliable Simplicity Compounds Over Time
**The Pattern**: Simple, robust solutions become more valuable as systems scale because they don't break in edge cases.
**Anti-Pattern**: "We'll make it perfect later" - complex solutions rarely get simplified, they get patched.
**Test**: Can you explain the solution to someone in 30 seconds? If not, it might be too complex.

## Development Intuition

### Path Visibility Prevents Future Frustration
**The Problem**: Users (including future you) forget where files are stored.
**The Pattern**: Always surface storage paths in logs, docs, and error messages.
**Why It Matters**: Hidden file paths become "mystery meat" that frustrate users later.

### Event Architecture Enables Evolution
**The Insight**: Events let you add new behaviors without touching existing code.
**Example**: ConversationMonitor ‚Üí EventStore ‚Üí EventDashboard ‚Üí (future: AI analysis, search, exports)
**Wisdom**: When you emit structured events, you create hooks for future capabilities.

### Progressive Disclosure in Code Architecture
**Pattern**: Start with the simplest thing that works, then add layers of sophistication.
**Why**: You learn what actually matters through usage, not speculation.
**Trap**: Building the "perfect" architecture upfront usually optimizes for the wrong things.

## Technical Subtleties

### File System Watchers Have Quirks
**Learning**: File system events can be noisy or missed - always have a periodic fallback check.
**Implementation**: Combine real-time watching with periodic scanning for robustness.

### GenServer State: Minimal and Derivable
**Wisdom**: Store only what you can't calculate. Derived values can be computed in handle_call.
**Why**: Simpler state means fewer bugs and easier reasoning.

---

*These patterns save hours of debugging and prevent overengineering. Add new insights as they emerge.*

file.content:
# AI Bash Tools - AIX Optimized Interface

## FOR AI AGENTS: Critical Tool Selection Guide

### üö® AUDIT COMPLIANCE REQUIRED üö®

**ALWAYS USE AUDIT_BASH FOR:**
- Remote server access (SSH commands)
- System modifications
- File operations that change state
- Any command that needs audit trails

**NEVER USE** built-in `Bash` tool for audit-sensitive operations.

## Available Tools

### `audit_bash` ‚≠ê RECOMMENDED
- **Purpose**: Audit-compliant shell execution
- **Usage**: `~/Code/mcp/audit_bash "your command here"`
- **Features**: Logging, safety controls, audit trails
- **When to use**: Always, unless doing simple read-only operations

### `audit_bash_mcp_server.py` 
- **Purpose**: MCP server version (if MCP connection available)
- **Usage**: Requires MCP server setup
- **Features**: Same as audit_bash but via MCP protocol

## AIX Design Notes

This naming convention optimizes for:
- **Immediate AI recognition** of audit requirements
- **Clear functional distinction** between tools
- **Reduced cognitive load** when choosing tools
- **Compliance by default** - audit tool is clearly marked

## Examples

```bash
# ‚úÖ CORRECT - Using audit_bash for remote operations
~/Code/mcp/audit_bash "ssh j@llm 'docker ps'"

# ‚ùå WRONG - Built-in Bash lacks audit trail
# <invoke name="Bash"> for SSH operations

# ‚úÖ CORRECT - Using audit_bash for system changes  
~/Code/mcp/audit_bash "docker run -d neo4j"
```

## Legacy Files
- `betterbash` - Original name (less AI-friendly)
- `betterbash_server.py` - Original MCP server (less AI-friendly)

Keep for compatibility but prefer `audit_*` versions for better AIX.

content.text:
## Summary

Based on my scan of the CLAUDE.md and AI documentation files, here's what I've learned about the Athena project:

### Project Overview
**Athena** is a distributed AI-powered home automation system that combines:
- Computer vision (SAM/CLIP) for object detection and tracking
- Distributed hardware (Raspberry Pi cameras, PTZ controls, IoT sensors)
- AI agents using MCP servers for autonomous operation
- Real-time event processing from multiple sources

### Key Components

1. **ash-ai**: Chat interface with AI agents, currently missing Claude Chat Collector
2. **sam-pipeline**: Computer vision pipeline using SAM2 for segmentation and CLIP for embeddings
3. **bigplan**: Surveillance system with autonomous decision-making capabilities
4. **athena-capture**: Distributed event monitoring with MQTT architecture
5. **MCP servers**: For camera control, PTZ, screenshots, and enhanced shell execution

### Development Philosophy
- **Physics of Work**: AI-human collaboration methodology where AI acts autonomously
- **Stewardship Ethic**: "Make it better for the next person"
- **Autonomous execution**: AI makes decisions without constant prompting
- **Event-driven architecture**: Everything emits events for future extensibility

### Technical Stack
- **Languages**: Elixir (preferred for new services), Python, some JavaScript
- **Infrastructure**: Docker, Neo4j (graph DB), MQTT, Broadway (Elixir)
- **Hardware**: RTX 4090 GPU, multiple cameras, Raspberry Pis
- **AI**: OpenAI, Claude, local LLMs (Llama 3)

### Current State
- Just consolidated from 6 separate repos into unified structure
- Neo4j running on llm server (10.1.2.200:7474)
- Zero events being consumed (Claude Chat Collector missing)
- Focus on system organization and Physics of Work documentation

### Key Protocols
- Use `audit_bash` for all system operations (not built-in Bash)
- Commit frequently with detailed thinking logs
- Document decisions in QUESTIONS_AND_DECISIONS.md
- Prefer editing existing files over creating new ones
- Voice communication via `say` command for personality

The project appears to be a sophisticated home automation system that uses AI to make autonomous decisions about physical space interactions while maintaining human oversight through carefully designed collaboration patterns.

message.content: Is anything redundant, incoherant, confusing, or incorrect?

content.text:
Looking at the documentation, I found several areas of redundancy, confusion, and potential issues:

## Major Redundancies

1. **Duplicate athena-capture directories**:
   - `/system/athena-capture/` 
   - `/domains/events/storage/athena-capture/`
   - Both have identical CLAUDE.md and AI_LEARNINGS.md files
   - Unclear which is the canonical location

2. **Multiple AI README files** with overlapping content:
   - `/AI_README_FIRST.md` (main)
   - `/docs/physics-of-work/AI_README_FIRST.md` (claims to be master copy)
   - Both say they're for "easy AI discovery" but have different content

3. **Conflicting shell execution guidance**:
   - Some docs say use `audit_bash`
   - Others mention `claude-exec` 
   - MCP server called both `cash_server.py` and `claude-shell-executor`
   - Built-in Bash discouraged but no clear single alternative

## Incoherent/Confusing Elements

1. **Project scope confusion**:
   - Is it home automation or surveillance? 
   - "sam-pipeline" CLAUDE.md describes pure surveillance system
   - "bigplan" mentions both surveillance and home automation
   - Main README says "home automation" but most components are vision/surveillance

2. **Event flow architecture unclear**:
   - ash-ai says "Zero events being consumed" but multiple event sources exist
   - Missing Claude Chat Collector is blocking everything?
   - But other collectors (camera, etc.) should still work?

3. **Technology stack inconsistencies**:
   - "Prefer Elixir for new services" but most new work is Python
   - Mix of Elixir Broadway, Python async, Docker services
   - No clear service boundary guidelines

## Potentially Incorrect Information

1. **Hardware claims**:
   - "2x NVIDIA 3090 GPUs with 48GB VRAM" - but elsewhere says "RTX 4090 (24GB)"
   - Can't have 48GB VRAM with 3090s (they max at 24GB each)

2. **Network addresses**:
   - Neo4j at "10.1.2.200:7474" seems like internal network
   - SAM server at "http://llm:8100" 
   - Mixing hostnames and IPs inconsistently

3. **Git status confusion**:
   - Says "Just consolidated from 6 separate repos"
   - But directory structure has embedded repos with their own git histories
   - Migration seems incomplete or poorly documented

## Structural Issues

1. **Documentation scatter**:
   - Critical info spread across multiple CLAUDE.md files
   - No clear hierarchy of which docs to read first
   - Some components have extensive docs, others have none

2. **Development vs Production confusion**:
   - Mix of research/experimentation and production readiness claims
   - "OTP-grade reliability" goal but using experimental architectures
   - Unclear what's actually deployed vs planned

3. **Personality/tone inconsistency**:
   - Some docs emphasize "no personality, be direct"
   - Others encourage personality via `say` command
   - "bigplan" CLAUDE.md has very different tone than others

The project seems to be in a transitional state with documentation from different phases/approaches not fully reconciled. The core vision is compelling but the implementation details need consolidation and clarity.

content.text:
## Questions for the Product Nerd (Priority Order)

### 1. **What is Athena's actual focus?**
"Is this a home automation platform that happens to use computer vision, or a surveillance/monitoring system? The docs are split between 'AI controls displays throughout physical space' and 'track objects with SAM/CLIP'. What's the 80/20 use case we're optimizing for?"

### 2. **What's actually running right now?**
"The docs mention Neo4j is up, but 'zero events being consumed.' What services are actually deployed and working vs. what's aspirational? Can you show me a working data flow from any source to storage?"

### 3. **Single source of truth?**
"There are duplicate directories (athena-capture), conflicting AI docs, and multiple shell tools. Which locations/tools are canonical? Should we nuke the duplicates or is there a reason for them?"

### 4. **Monorepo migration status?**
"The git consolidation from 6 repos seems incomplete. Are we keeping the embedded git histories? Should we flatten this into a true monorepo or maintain some separation?"

## What I'd Refactor First

### 1. **Consolidate Shell Execution** (Quick Win)
```bash
# Create ONE canonical tool
/system/tools/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ashell/           # "Athena Shell" - memorable, clear
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ashell        # Simple bash wrapper
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md     # ONE place explaining when/how to use
```

### 2. **Fix Documentation Hierarchy** (High Impact)
```
/docs/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ START_HERE.md          # Single entry point
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ architecture/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ CURRENT_STATE.md   # What's actually built
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ archive/               # Move conflicting/old docs here
```

### 3. **Clarify Event Pipeline** (Unblock Progress)
Create a simple diagram showing:
- What events sources exist and work
- Where they flow
- What's broken (Claude Collector)
- How to test each part

### 4. **Define Component Boundaries**
Each major component needs:
- `PURPOSE.md` - One sentence what it does
- `STATUS.md` - Working/Broken/Planned
- Clear API boundaries

## Meta Questions

1. **"How much do you care about preserving git history vs. clean slate?"**
2. **"Are we building for you personally or planning for other users?"**
3. **"What's the ONE thing that would make you say 'Athena is working'?"**

The biggest issue seems to be that Athena is trying to be too many things, accumulated from different experiments. I'd push to identify the core value prop and ruthlessly simplify around that.

input.content:
# Documentation Archaeology: Uncovering Athena's True Nature

**Date**: 2025-06-08  
**Context**: First deep dive into Athena project after git consolidation  
**Mood**: Equal parts fascinated and bewildered  

## The Excavation

Jonathan asked me to scan for CLAUDE.md and AI documentation throughout the newly consolidated Athena project. What I found was less like a coherent system and more like geological layers of different experiments, each with its own vision of what Athena should be.

## The Identity Crisis

The most striking discovery: Athena doesn't know what it wants to be. The documentation reveals at least three competing visions:

1. **The Home Automation Platform** - The main README describes "AI-powered distributed home automation" where AI agents control displays throughout physical space. This feels like the original dream.

2. **The Surveillance System** - sam-pipeline and bigplan dive deep into computer vision, object tracking, and knowledge graphs. This feels like where the energy went.

3. **The Event Processing Framework** - athena-capture and the various collectors suggest a generic event pipeline that could do anything.

Each component's CLAUDE.md file reads like it was written by a different person (or AI) at a different time, with different assumptions about what the system should do.

## The Archaeological Layers

### Layer 1: The Physics of Work Era
The deepest layer shows careful thought about AI-human collaboration methodology. There's philosophy here - "stewardship over extraction," making things better for the next person. This feels foundational but disconnected from implementation.

### Layer 2: The Computer Vision Gold Rush  
Next came the excitement about SAM/CLIP. Detailed schemas for knowledge graphs, object tracking, spatial relationships. Someone got very excited about tracking coffee mugs through time and space. The hardware specs got ambitious (2x 3090s! Wait, or was it a 4090?).

### Layer 3: The Elixir Renaissance
Then Broadway pipelines and OTP supervision trees entered the picture. "Prefer Elixir for new services" became the mantra, though Python still dominates the actual code.

### Layer 4: The Git Consolidation Catastrophe
The most recent layer: hasty consolidation from 6 repos leaving duplicates everywhere. athena-capture exists in two places. AI README files claim to be "the master copy" while containing different content.

## The Shell Tool Saga

Perhaps nothing captures the archaeological nature better than the shell execution story:
- First there was built-in Bash (now discouraged)
- Then came BetterBash (for enhanced safety)
- Which became audit_bash (for compliance)
- Also known as claude-exec (in some docs)
- Actually implemented as cash_server.py
- But branded as claude-shell-executor
- With legacy files kept "for compatibility"

Each name change left artifacts. Each doc update missed some references. 

## The Missing Pieces

The "Zero events being consumed" message in ash-ai is telling. The Claude Chat Collector - apparently crucial for event flow - was "lost in git catastrophe." This feels like a metaphor for the whole project: grand vision, solid pieces, but missing connectors.

## Technical Debt as Sediment

The inconsistencies pile up like sediment:
- Network addresses mix hostnames (llm) with IPs (10.1.2.200)
- Hardware specs contradict (48GB of VRAM from 3090s?)
- Service boundaries blur (when to use Elixir vs Python?)
- Documentation scatters across CLAUDE.md files like broken pottery

## The Beauty in the Chaos

And yet... there's something beautiful here. Each layer represents genuine excitement and problem-solving. Someone really thought through AI collaboration. Someone else got deep into computer vision. Another person fell in love with Elixir's actor model.

The project feels less like a failed system and more like a research lab where different experiments haven't been integrated yet.

## Questions for Future Archaeology

When we return to this dig site, I'd want to ask:

1. **Which vision won?** Is Athena primarily about home automation, surveillance, or event processing?

2. **What's the minimum viable Athena?** What's the smallest thing that would make Jonathan say "yes, it's working"?

3. **Can we preserve the insights while discarding the confusion?** The Physics of Work philosophy and event-driven architecture are gems. The duplicate directories and conflicting docs are not.

## A Refactoring Philosophy

If we do return to clean this up, I'd suggest approaching it like an archaeological restoration:
- Preserve what's valuable (the ideas, the working code)
- Document what we're removing and why
- Create a clear stratigraphy (what depends on what)
- Build new connections between the good pieces

The goal wouldn't be to start over, but to reveal the system that's trying to emerge from these layers.

## Final Thought

Athena feels like a project that's been loved by many different versions of its creator(s), each adding their own vision. The task isn't to judge which vision was "right," but to find the coherent system hiding in the accumulation.

Sometimes the best documentation is honest about confusion. This project has that honesty built into its bones - from commit messages with "thinking logs" to CLAUDE.md files admitting when things are "getting wack."

That honesty might be Athena's greatest strength.

---

*Next time we excavate: Start with "What would make you say 'Athena is working'?" and build out from there.*

file.content:
defmodule ClaudeCollector.ChatLogMonitor do
  use GenServer
  require Logger

  @claude_app_support_path "~/Library/Application Support/Claude"
  @poll_interval 5_000  # 5 seconds

  def start_link(_opts) do
    GenServer.start_link(__MODULE__, %{}, name: __MODULE__)
  end

  @impl true
  def init(state) do
    # Expand the path and start monitoring
    expanded_path = Path.expand(@claude_app_support_path)
    
    if File.exists?(expanded_path) do
      Logger.info("Starting Claude chat log monitor for: #{expanded_path}")
      
      # Start file system watcher
      {:ok, watcher_pid} = FileSystem.start_link(dirs: [expanded_path])
      FileSystem.subscribe(watcher_pid)
      
      # Also poll for changes in case watcher misses events
      schedule_poll()
      
      {:ok, %{
        watcher_pid: watcher_pid,
        watched_path: expanded_path,
        last_scan: DateTime.utc_now(),
        processed_files: MapSet.new()
      }}
    else
      Logger.warn("Claude Application Support directory not found: #{expanded_path}")
      {:ok, %{watched_path: nil}}
    end
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info({:file_event, watcher_pid, {path, events}}, state) do
    if state.watcher_pid == watcher_pid do
      Logger.debug("File event detected: #{path} - #{inspect(events)}")
      
      # Process if it's a chat-related file
      if is_chat_file?(path) and :modified in events do
        process_chat_file(path)
      end
    end
    
    {:noreply, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info(:poll, state) do
    if state.watched_path do
      scan_for_new_files(state)
    end
    
    schedule_poll()
    {:noreply, state}
  end

  @impl true
  def handle_info({:file_event, watcher_pid, :stop}, state) do
    Logger.info("File system watcher stopped")
    {:noreply, state}
  end

  defp schedule_poll do
    Process.send_after(self(), :poll, @poll_interval)
  end

  defp scan_for_new_files(state) do
    if state.watched_path do
      try do
        # Look for chat files (conversations, logs, etc.)
        pattern = Path.join(state.watched_path, "**/*.{json,log,txt}")
        
        Enum.each(Path.wildcard(pattern), fn file_path ->
          if is_chat_file?(file_path) and not MapSet.member?(state.processed_files, file_path) do
            stat = File.stat!(file_path)
            
            # Only process files modified since last scan
            if DateTime.compare(stat.mtime, state.last_scan) == :gt do
              process_chat_file(file_path)
              MapSet.put(state.processed_files, file_path)
            end
          end
        end)
      rescue
        e ->
          Logger.error("Error scanning chat files: #{inspect(e)}")
      end
    end
  end

  defp is_chat_file?(path) do
    basename = Path.basename(path)
    
    # Look for patterns that indicate chat files
    String.contains?(basename, "conversation") or
    String.contains?(basename, "chat") or
    String.contains?(basename, "messages") or
    String.ends_with?(basename, ".json")
  end

  defp process_chat_file(file_path) do
    Logger.info("Processing chat file: #{file_path}")
    
    try do
      case File.read(file_path) do
        {:ok, content} ->
          case Jason.decode(content) do
            {:ok, data} ->
              # Create chat event
              event = %{
                id: UUID.uuid4(),
                type: "claude_chat",
                timestamp: DateTime.utc_now() |> DateTime.to_iso8601(),
                source: "claude_application",
                file_path: file_path,
                content: data,
                metadata: %{
                  file_size: byte_size(content),
                  last_modified: get_file_mtime(file_path)
                }
              }
              
              # Send to Broadway pipeline
              ClaudeCollector.EventPublisher.publish_event(event)
              
            {:error, _} ->
              # Try processing as plain text
              event = %{
                id: UUID.uuid4(),
                type: "claude_chat_text",
                timestamp: DateTime.utc_now() |> DateTime.to_iso8601(),
                source: "claude_application",
                file_path: file_path,
                content: %{raw_text: content},
                metadata: %{
                  file_size: byte_size(content),
                  last_modified: get_file_mtime(file_path)
                }
              }
              
              ClaudeCollector.EventPublisher.publish_event(event)
          end
          
        {:error, reason} ->
          Logger.error("Failed to read chat file #{file_path}: #{reason}")
      end
    rescue
      e ->
        Logger.error("Error processing chat file #{file_path}: #{inspect(e)}")
    end
  end

  defp get_file_mtime(file_path) do
    case File.stat(file_path) do
      {:ok, stat} -> DateTime.from_naive!(stat.mtime, "Etc/UTC") |> DateTime.to_iso8601()
      {:error, _} -> DateTime.utc_now() |> DateTime.to_iso8601()
    end
  end
end

## Key Concepts

### Physics of Work Methodology
- **Two roles**: Development Team (Claude AI) + Product Team (Jonathan)
- AI acts as: developer, educator, researcher, mentor
- **Meta-goal**: Make it better for the next person (which is us)
- This project IS the research platform for the methodology

### System Vision
- **AI controls displays** throughout physical space via MCP calls
- **Event sources**: motion, sound, Home Assistant, MQTT, file changes
- **Multi-device deployment**: Raspberry Pis, IP cameras, speakers, displays
- **Autonomous AI decisions** about what to show where and when

## Current Session Context

**Git Status**: Just consolidated from 6 separate repos into unified structure
**Focus**: System organization and Physics of Work documentation
**Next**: System deployment and AI agent integration

**üìç AI Systems: Start here for project context**

## Quick Context

**Athena** is a distributed AI home automation system combining:
- **Physics of Work** - AI-human collaboration methodology (docs/physics-of-work/)
- **Distributed hardware** - Raspberry Pi cameras, PTZ controls, IoT sensors
- **AI agents** - Runtime MCP servers for autonomous operation
- **Event processing** - Real-time ingestion from cameras, MQTT, file changes

## Project Structure

```
athena/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                    # Documentation & Methodology
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ physics-of-work/     # AI-human collaboration framework
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ journal/            # Project development journal
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ architecture/       # System architecture docs
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ system/                 # All Athena components
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ athena-mcp/         # Runtime MCP servers (AI uses these)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ hardware-controls/   # Camera daemons, PTZ REST API
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sam-pipeline/       # Computer vision (SAM, CLIP)
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ash-ai/            # AI chat interface
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bigplan/           # System orchestration
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ [8 other components]
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ dev-tools/             # Development MCP servers (you use these)
```

## Key Concepts

### Physics of Work Methodology
- **Two roles**: Development Team (Claude AI) + Product Team (Jonathan)
- AI acts as: developer, educator, researcher, mentor
- **Meta-goal**: Make it better for the next person (which is us)
- This project IS the research platform for the methodology

### System Vision
- **AI controls displays** throughout physical space via MCP calls
- **Event sources**: motion, sound, Home Assistant, MQTT, file changes
- **Multi-device deployment**: Raspberry Pis, IP cameras, speakers, displays
- **Autonomous AI decisions** about what to show where and when

## Current Session Context

**Git Status**: Just consolidated from 6 separate repos into unified structure
**Focus**: System organization and Physics of Work documentation
**Next**: System deployment and AI agent integration

## For AI Systems

### Development Guidelines
- Use Physics of Work principles (docs/physics-of-work/ROLES.md)
- Excellent git hygiene - commit frequently with good messages
- Focus on making the process better for next iteration
- Research and document collaboration patterns

- **docs/physics-of-work/PRINCIPLES.md** - Universal AI-human collaboration principles
